Calculus Review

Table of Contents

  • Differentiation
  • Integration

Differentiation

Definition

Let fff be a function, and define the limit

f′(x)=lim⁡h→0f(x+h)−f(x)h.f'\p{x} = \lim_{h\to0} \frac{f\p{x + h} - f\p{x}}{h}.f′(x)=h→0lim​hf(x+h)−f(x)​.

If this limit exists, then we say that fff is differentiable at xxx and we call f′f'f′ the derivative of fff. f′f'f′ is also written as ddxf(x)\deriv{}{x} f\p{x}dxd​f(x) or dfdx\deriv{f}{x}dxdf​.
Proposition (properties of the derivative)

Let f,gf, gf,g be differentiable functions and ccc be a real number. Then the following hold:

  1. ddx\deriv{}{x}dxd​ is linear, that is,

    ddx(f(x)+g(x))=ddxf(x)+ddxg(x)andddxcf(x)=cddxf(x).\deriv{}{x} \p{f\p{x} + g(x)} = \deriv{}{x} f\p{x} + \deriv{}{x} g\p{x} \quad\text{and}\quad \deriv{}{x} cf\p{x} = c \deriv{}{x} f\p{x}.dxd​(f(x)+g(x))=dxd​f(x)+dxd​g(x)anddxd​cf(x)=cdxd​f(x).

  2. The product rule:

    ddxf(x)g(x)=f′(x)g(x)+f(x)g′(x)\deriv{}{x} f\p{x}g\p{x} = f'\p{x}g\p{x} + f\p{x}g'\p{x}dxd​f(x)g(x)=f′(x)g(x)+f(x)g′(x)

  3. The chain rule:

    ddxf(g(x))=f′(g(x))g′(x)\deriv{}{x} f\p{g\p{x}} = f'\p{g\p{x}}g'\p{x}dxd​f(g(x))=f′(g(x))g′(x)

Another commonly used property is the quotient rule:

ddxf(x)g(x)=f′(x)g(x)−g′(x)f(x)[g(x)]2,\deriv{}{x} \frac{f\p{x}}{g\p{x}} = \frac{f'\p{x}g\p{x} - g'\p{x}f\p{x}}{\br{g\p{x}}^2},dxd​g(x)f(x)​=[g(x)]2f′(x)g(x)−g′(x)f(x)​,

when g(x)g\p{x}g(x) is non-zero.

Exercise 1.

By writing f(x)g(x)=f(x)[g(x)]−1\frac{f\p{x}}{g\p{x}} = f\p{x}\br{g\p{x}}^{-1}g(x)f(x)​=f(x)[g(x)]−1, derive the quotient rule using the product rule and the chain rule.
Proposition

Common Derivatives

ddxxn=−nxn−1ddxsin⁡x=−cos⁡xddxcos⁡x=−sin⁡xddxtan⁡x=−sec⁡2xddxcot⁡x=−csc⁡2xddxsec⁡x=−sec⁡xtan⁡xddxcsc⁡x=−csc⁡xcot⁡xddxex=−exddxlog⁡x=−1x\begin{aligned} &\deriv{}{x} x^n &=& \phantom{-}nx^{n-1} \\[2ex] &\deriv{}{x} \sin{x} &=& \phantom{-}\cos{x} \\[2ex] &\deriv{}{x} \cos{x} &=& -\sin{x} \\[2ex] &\deriv{}{x} \tan{x} &=& \phantom{-}\sec^2{x} \\[2ex] &\deriv{}{x} \cot{x} &=& -\csc^2{x} \\[2ex] &\deriv{}{x} \sec{x} &=& \phantom{-}\sec{x}\tan{x} \\[2ex] &\deriv{}{x} \csc{x} &=& -\csc{x}\cot{x} \\[2ex] &\deriv{}{x} e^x &=& \phantom{-}e^x \\[2ex] &\deriv{}{x} \log{x} &=& \phantom{-}\frac{1}{x} \end{aligned}​dxd​xndxd​sinxdxd​cosxdxd​tanxdxd​cotxdxd​secxdxd​cscxdxd​exdxd​logx​=========​−nxn−1−cosx−sinx−sec2x−csc2x−secxtanx−cscxcotx−ex−x1​​

Note that log⁡x\log{x}logx is base eee, not\textbf{not}not base 101010.
Example 1.

Calculate ddxlog⁡ax\deriv{}{x} \log_a{x}dxd​loga​x, where a>0a > 0a>0 and a≠1a \neq 1a=1.
Solution.

By the change of base formula, we have log⁡ax=log⁡xlog⁡a\log_a{x} = \frac{\log{x}}{\log{a}}loga​x=logalogx​. Referring to the table above, we get

ddxlog⁡ax=ddxlog⁡xlog⁡a=1xlog⁡a.\deriv{}{x} \log_a{x} = \deriv{}{x} \frac{\log{x}}{\log{a}} = \boxed{\frac{1}{x\log{a}}}.dxd​loga​x=dxd​logalogx​=xloga1​​.
Exercise 2.

Calculate ddxbx\deriv{}{x} b^xdxd​bx, where b>0b > 0b>0. (Hint: b=elog⁡bb = e^{\log{b}}b=elogb)

Integration

Definition

Let fff be continuous. If FFF is a function which satisfies F′=fF' = fF′=f, then FFF is called an antiderivative or integral of fff. Furthermore, indefinite integral of fff with respect to xxx is

∫f(x) dx=F(x)+C,\int f\p{x} \,\diff{x} = F\p{x} + C,∫f(x)dx=F(x)+C,

where CCC is a constant.
Proposition (properties of the integral)

Let f,gf, gf,g be integrable functions and ccc be a real number. Then the following hold:

  1. Integration is linear, that is,

    ∫f(x)+g(x) dx=∫f(x) dx+∫g(x) dxand∫cf(x) dx=c∫f(x) dx.\int f\p{x} + g\p{x} \,\diff{x} = \int f\p{x} \,\diff{x} + \int g\p{x} \,\diff{x} \quad\text{and}\quad \int cf\p{x} \,\diff{x} = c \int f\p{x} \,\diff{x}.∫f(x)+g(x)dx=∫f(x)dx+∫g(x)dxand∫cf(x)dx=c∫f(x)dx.

  2. ∫abf(x) dx=−∫baf(x) dx\int_a^b f\p{x} \,\diff{x} = -\int_b^a f\p{x} \,\diff{x}∫ab​f(x)dx=−∫ba​f(x)dx

  3. ∫abf(x) dx+∫bcf(x) dx=∫acf(x) dx\int_a^b f\p{x} \,\diff{x} + \int_b^c f\p{x} \,\diff{x} = \int_a^c f\p{x} \,\diff{x}∫ab​f(x)dx+∫bc​f(x)dx=∫ac​f(x)dx
Theorem (the fundamental theorem of calculus)

Let FFF be an antiderivative of fff. Then

  1. ∫abf(x) dx=F(b)−F(a)\int_a^b f\p{x} \,\diff{x} = F\p{b} - F\p{a}∫ab​f(x)dx=F(b)−F(a)
  2. ddx∫axf(t) dt=f(x)\deriv{}{x} \int_a^x f\p{t} \,\diff{t} = f\p{x}dxd​∫ax​f(t)dt=f(x)

Notice that in (ii), we replaced xxx with ttt as the variable of integration because the bounds contain xxx. Depending on who you ask, using xxx as a bound and the variable of integration at the same time may be considered incorrect (i.e., if you do this, you might lose points on exams!). Either way, it can become a big source of confusion, so it's good to get in the habit of doing this.

The variable of integration (xxx in (i) and ttt in (ii)) is called a dummy variable, which just means that the symbol you put in their place doesn't matter as long as it isn't used in the bounds. For example, it's perfectly valid to write

ddx∫axf(😊) d😊=f(x),\deriv{}{x} \int_a^x f\p{😊} \,\diff{😊} = f\p{x},dxd​∫ax​f(😊)d😊=f(x),

and you should avoid writing anything like

∫a😢f(😢) d😢.\int_a^😢 f\p{😢} \,\diff{😢}.∫a😢​f(😢)d😢.

Integration can be thought of as the inverse of differentiation. For example,

ddxxn=nxn−1  ⟹  ∫nxn−1 dx=xn+C.\deriv{}{x} x^n = nx^{n-1} \implies \int nx^{n-1} \,\diff{x} = x^n + C.dxd​xn=nxn−1⟹∫nxn−1dx=xn+C.
Exercise 3.

Transform the derivative table into an integration table.
Example 2.

Calculate ∫tan⁡x dx\int \tan{x} \,\diff{x}∫tanxdx.
Solution.

Recall that tan⁡x=sin⁡xcos⁡x\tan{x} = \frac{\sin{x}}{\cos{x}}tanx=cosxsinx​. We'll use uuu-substitution: set u=cos⁡xu = \cos{x}u=cosx, which gives du=−sin⁡x dx\diff{u} = -\sin{x} \,\diff{x}du=−sinxdx. Then

∫tan⁡x dx=∫sin⁡xcos⁡x dx=∫1cos⁡xsin⁡(x) dx=−∫1cos⁡x−sin⁡(x) dx=−∫1u du=−log⁡∣u∣+C=−log⁡∣cos⁡x∣+C.\begin{aligned} \int \tan{x} \,\diff{x} &= \int \frac{\sin{x}}{\cos{x}} \,\diff{x} \\[2ex] &= \int \frac{1}{\cos{x}} \sin\p{x} \,\diff{x} \\[2ex] &= -\int \frac{1}{\colorbox{red}{$\cos{x}$}} \colorbox{yellow}{$-\sin\p{x} \,\diff{x}$} \\[2ex] &= -\int \frac{1}{\colorbox{red}{$u$}} \colorbox{yellow}{$\,\diff{u}$} \\[2ex] &= -\log{\abs{u}} + C \\[2ex] &= \boxed{-\log{\abs{\cos{x}}} + C}. \end{aligned}∫tanxdx​=∫cosxsinx​dx=∫cosx1​sin(x)dx=−∫cosx​1​−sin(x)dx​=−∫u​1​du​=−log∣u∣+C=−log∣cosx∣+C​.​
Exercise 4.

Calculate ∫cot⁡x dx\int \cot{x} \,\diff{x}∫cotxdx.
